content.rendered:
You need to mass create community users? Well you totally can! Here are the steps and some gotchas to keep in mind.

The Data

First you want the assess if the Users you want to create as Community Users already have Accounts and Contacts in the system. There are 3 objects with Community User creation:

  • The Account the User’s Contact is associated with
  • The Contact associated with the User
  • The User record itself

You don’t want to make duplicate records. Check for duplicates using the Email address, which is more likely to find a true match.

Match up any existing data for Accounts and Contacts with the Users you plan to make. I recommend off the Contact match via email, grab your fields like such:

SELECT FirstName,LastName, AccountId, Account.Name, Id, Email, Phone, MailingStreet, MailingState, MailingCity, MailingCountry, MailingPostalCode FROM Contact

For data you don’t find the match, it needs to be created…

Accounts & Contacts

First import your user’s Accounts they relate to if you don’t have. Make sure you save the ID’s if using DataLoader. You want the AccountId to map for your new Contacts.

As a side note, make sure the Owner on the Account, be it new or existing, has a role. You can’t create community users without a role on the Account Owner

Map the Id from the Account to the AccountId on the Contact. Then, import your contacts associated with the accounts you created. Map your Account.Name to the Id via the VLOOKUP to have the Company and AccountId.

Additional Note: If using the import wizard you can import both Accounts and Contacts together at once in a single import.

Users

Next up we have our last data load, to create the Users. Before diving into how to setup the User data, I want to cover a few gotchas.

  • First that user needs a Contact
  • That Contact Must be on an Account
  • If using PersonAccounts you need the PrimaryContactId from the Account,
    • Partners, they cannot be PersonAccounts.
  • If your licenses are CC+ or Partner, the Roles you have for community users will not exist yet if you don’t have Community Users on the Account already.
    • Meaning if the Account is new or doesn’t have any associated Contacts with Users it won’t have all the roles.
    • I recommend importing the users without a role, thus assigning the auto created role of [Account] “User Role”.
    • From there you can change the role post creation.
  • The Owner on the Account must have a role, as mentioned above

User Creation Steps

First, you need to make the data set, take the Contacts you found that match or that you just imported, and use that Id for the ContactId on the User. Next, you also need to get the related ProfileId based on the community’s Profile(s) and the permissions the user should be assigned. I recommend your own map for Profiles whit your own key or a picklist.

Required Fields and their Mappings:

With your User fields mapped, and the required fields populated, you’re ready to import. Then import your Users, and post import and activation of the user will then have the following actions:

  • The additional User Roles are auto generated
  • Checking of the IsCustomerEnabled automatically on the Account
  • Sending of the welcome email

Additional Tip: I recommend adding the Address to the user as well, for better data, and don’t forget your internal custom required fields too.

Welcome Email

The next most important items when creating users is the Community Welcome Email. Before you create your users in mass, document your plan of attack here, why you ask? Simple, you have multiple choices, each with it’s own flare designed for different situations

Add Profiles then Upload Users As Active

Add your user profiles to Members in the Community Administration and check the “send welcome email” box. Then Use the Data Loader to mass upload your users as active and they will automatically receive the welcome email.

  • Best for net new orgs with no data migration or for net new community users.
  • If you use this option for a migration from another system, make sure you migrate all the other related data (cases, leads, etc.) shortly after, as users will be able to login as soon as they receive the notification.

Upload Users, then Add Profiles

Assuming the community is new and has no members, first upload your users with Data Loader. After data has been migrated, add their profile to the community and all users will receive the welcome email.

  • This option solves the historical data issue in option 1 above giving you plenty of time to migrate other data before triggering the email.
  • Will not work if you are adding more users to a profile that already has active community members (you would have to remove them from the community first).

Clone Existing Profile, Upload Users, Add Profiles

Assuming the community already has users, the above options won’t work as well. Instead, clone a profile with the permissions you need for your new users, assign them to this profile, and once users are created, add the profile to the community.

  • Works best if you have an existing community with members up and running, and just need to add a new set of users.
  • Once this is done, you can leave users assigned to the new cloned profile, or update them all to the original profile (to avoid profile proliferation)

Boom! Community Users mass created and ready to login!

Resources

  • Knowledge Article: Mass Users Create Portal
  • User Import Sheets Template
  • Mass create users

excerpt.rendered: Learn all about Mass Community User creation in this post, with everything from mappings to links to the User Template to Welcome email send.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 2: Guest Page Visibility
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: This post we expore guest user visibily in Experience Cloud. Every Community has a Guest User and Guest User Profile. A guest is someone that can see your community before they login - an Unauthenticated user. Each time a community or portal is created, Salesforce auto-creates a guest user profile…

img.alt_text: Community Sharing part 2_ Guest Page Visibility

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 1: Sharing Sets – Your First Step in Sharing
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Sharing Sets are an amazing superpower that comes with your Communities. They are a way to share with Community License types and Community users. Keep in mind, this type of security and sharing is only available for your community users, it is not available to share with internal users.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Native CMS
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Out of the box you you have 3 types of CMS, native CMS is one of those 3. Learn all about it from how to create articles, use cases, and why use Native CMS.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 3: Channel Programs
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: We have talked about Sharing Sets, Page Visibility and Guests, now we are going a bit of a different directions, how to take those pages and take the users and find out how to make then into different groups for audiences, folders, sharing groups, managing resources, and standard partner categories…

jetpack-related-posts.title: List Custom Settings
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: What is a Custom Setting?  We talked about Hierarchy Custom Settings in the Keep Clean Validation Rules with Custom Settings post, which let you set a default field value for the organization, then you can assign a value to a Profile or User.  List Custom Settings are a bit different, they don't…

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect 18 Updates
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!
